Climate|  Diverse: Ranges from Temperate in the North to Tropical in the far
south. West: mostly semi-arid to desert, Mountains: alpine, Northeast: humid
continental, Southeast: humid subtropical, Coast of California: Mediterranean,
Pacific Northwest: cool temperate oceanic, Alaska: mostly subarctic, Hawaii,
South Florida, and the territories: tropical  
Terrain|  Vast central plain, Interior Highlands and low mountains in Midwest,
mountains and valleys in the mid-south, coastal flatland near the Gulf and
Atlantic coasts, complete with mangrove forests and temperate, subtropical,
and tropical laurel forest and jungle, canyons, basins, plateus, and mountains
in west, hills and low mountains in east; intermittent hilly and mountainous
regions in Great Plains, with occasional badland topography; rugged mountains

Natural Hazards|  tsunamis; volcanoes; earthquake activity around Pacific
Basin; hurricanes along the Atlantic and Gulf of Mexico coasts; tornadoes in
the Midwest and Southeast; mud slides in California; forest fires in the west;
flooding; permafrost in northern Alaska  
Environmental Issues|  severe water shortages, air pollution resulting in acid
rain in both the US and Canada  
  
The term "[United States](/wiki/United_States "United States")", when used in
the geographical sense, is the [contiguous United
States](/wiki/Contiguous_United_States "Contiguous United States"), the state
of [Alaska](/wiki/Alaska "Alaska"), the island state of [Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii
"Hawaii"), the five insular [territories](/wiki/United_States_territory
"United States territory") of [Puerto Rico](/wiki/Puerto_Rico "Puerto Rico"),
[Northern Mariana Islands](/wiki/Northern_Mariana_Islands "Northern Mariana
Islands"), [U.S. Virgin Islands](/wiki/United_States_Virgin_Islands "United
States Virgin Islands"), [Guam](/wiki/Guam "Guam"), and [American
Samoa](/wiki/American_Samoa "American Samoa"), and [minor outlying
possessions](/wiki/Insular_area "Insular area").[1] The United States shares
land borders with [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada") and [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico
"Mexico") and maritime borders with [Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia"),
[Cuba](/wiki/Cuba "Cuba"), and [the Bahamas](/wiki/The_Bahamas "The Bahamas")
in addition to Canada and Mexico. The United States's northern border [with
Canada](/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_border "Canada–United States
border") is the world's longest bi-national land border.

##
Area[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Area")]

From 1989 through 1996, the total area of the US was listed as 9,372,610 km2
(3,618,780 sq mi) (land + inland water only). The listed total area changed to
9,629,091 km2 (3,717,813 sq mi) in 1997 (Great Lakes area and coastal waters
added), to 9,631,418 km2 (3,718,711 sq mi) in 2004, to 9,631,420 km2
(3,718,710 sq mi) in 2006, and to 9,826,630 km2 (3,794,080 sq mi) in 2007
(territorial waters added). Currently, the CIA _World Factbook_ gives
9,826,675 km2 (3,794,100 sq mi),[2] the [United Nations Statistics
Division](/wiki/United_Nations_Statistics_Division "United Nations Statistics
Division") gives 9,629,091 km2 (3,717,813 sq mi),[3] and the _Encyclopædia
Britannica_ gives 9,522,055 km2 (3,676,486 sq mi)(Great Lakes area included
but not coastal waters).[4] These sources consider only the 50 states and the
Federal District, and exclude overseas territories.

By [total area](/wiki/List_of_countries_and_outlying_territories_by_total_area
"List of countries and outlying territories by total area")
([water](/wiki/Territorial_waters "Territorial waters") as well as land), the
United States is either slightly larger or smaller than the [People's Republic
of China](/wiki/People%27s_Republic_of_China "People's Republic of China"),
making it the world's third or fourth largest country. China and the United
States are smaller than [Russia](/wiki/Russia "Russia") and
[Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada") in total area, but are larger than
[Brazil](/wiki/Brazil "Brazil"). By land area only (exclusive of waters), the
United States is the world's third largest country, after Russia and China,
with Canada in fourth. Whether the US or China is the third largest country by
total area depends on two factors: (1) The validity of China's claim on [Aksai
Chin](/wiki/Aksai_Chin "Aksai Chin") and [Trans-Karakoram Tract](/wiki/Trans-
Karakoram_Tract "Trans-Karakoram Tract"). Both these territories are also
claimed by India, so are not counted; and (2) How US calculates its own
surface area. Since the initial publishing of the World Factbook, the CIA has
updated the total area of United States a number of times.[5]

## General
characteristics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: General characteristics")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/03/USA-
satellite.jpg/450px-USA-satellite.jpg)](/wiki/File:USA-satellite.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:USA-satellite.jpg "Enlarge")

A satellite composite image of the [contiguous United
States](/wiki/Contiguous_United_States "Contiguous United States").
[Deciduous](/wiki/Deciduous "Deciduous") vegetation and
[grasslands](/wiki/Grassland "Grassland") prevail in the east, transitioning
to [prairies](/wiki/Prairie "Prairie"), [boreal forests](/wiki/Boreal_forest
"Boreal forest"), and the [Rockies](/wiki/Rocky_Mountains "Rocky Mountains")
in the west, and [deserts](/wiki/Desert "Desert") in the southwest. In the
northeast, the coasts of the [Great Lakes](/wiki/Great_Lakes "Great Lakes")
and [Atlantic seaboard](/wiki/Atlantic_seaboard "Atlantic seaboard") host much
of the country's population.

The United States shares land borders with Canada (to the north) and Mexico
(to the south), and a [territorial water](/wiki/Territorial_waters
"Territorial waters") border with Russia in the northwest, and two territorial
water borders in the southeast between Florida and Cuba, and Florida and the
Bahamas. The contiguous forty-eight states are otherwise bounded by the
[Pacific Ocean](/wiki/Pacific_Ocean "Pacific Ocean") on the west, the
[Atlantic Ocean](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean") on the east, and the
[Gulf of Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of Mexico") to the southeast.
Alaska borders the Pacific Ocean to the south and southwest, the [Bering
Strait](/wiki/Bering_Strait "Bering Strait") to the west, and the [Arctic
Ocean](/wiki/Arctic_Ocean "Arctic Ocean") to the north, while Hawaii lies far
to the southwest of the mainland in the Pacific Ocean.

Forty-eight of the states are in the single region between Canada and Mexico;
this group is referred to, with varying precision and formality, as the
_continental_ or _[contiguous United States](/wiki/Contiguous_United_States
"Contiguous United States")_ , and as the _Lower 48_. Alaska, which is not
included in the term _contiguous United States_ , is at the northwestern end
of [North America](/wiki/North_America "North America"), separated from the
Lower 48 by Canada.

The capital city, [Washington, District of Columbia](/wiki/Washington,_D.C.
"Washington, D.C."), is a federal district located on land donated by the
state of [Maryland](/wiki/Maryland "Maryland"). ([Virginia](/wiki/Virginia
"Virginia") had also donated land, but it was returned in 1849.) The United
States also has [overseas territories](/wiki/Insular_area "Insular area") with
varying levels of independence and organization: in the
[Caribbean](/wiki/Caribbean_Sea "Caribbean Sea") the territories of Puerto
Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands, and in the Pacific the inhabited territories
of Guam, American Samoa, and the Northern Mariana Islands, along with a number
of uninhabited island territories.

## Physiographic
divisions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Physiographic divisions")]

Main article: [United States physiographic
region](/wiki/United_States_physiographic_region "United States physiographic
region")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/39/MountMcKinley_BA.jpg/300px-
MountMcKinley_BA.jpg)](/wiki/File:MountMcKinley_BA.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:MountMcKinley_BA.jpg "Enlarge")

[Denali](/wiki/Denali "Denali"), Alaska, the highest point in [North
America](/wiki/North_America "North America") at 20,310 ft (6,190.5 m).

The eastern United States has a varied topography. A broad, flat coastal plain
lines the Atlantic and Gulf shores from the Texas-Mexico border to New York
City, and includes the Florida peninsula. Areas further inland feature rolling
hills, mountains, and a diverse collection of temperate and subtropical moist
and wet forests. The [Appalachian Mountains](/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains
"Appalachian Mountains") form a line of low mountains separating the eastern
seaboard from the Great Lakes and the Mississippi Basin.

The five [Great Lakes](/wiki/Great_Lakes "Great Lakes") are located in the
north-central portion of the country, four of them forming part of the border
with [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada"), only [Lake Michigan](/wiki/Lake_Michigan
"Lake Michigan") situated entirely within United States. The southeast United
States, generally stretching from the [Ohio River](/wiki/Ohio_River "Ohio
River") on south, includes a variety of warm temperate and subtropical moist
and wet forests, as well as warm temperate and subtropical dry forests nearer
the Great Plains in the west of the region. West of the Appalachians lies the
lush [Mississippi River](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi River") basin
and two large eastern tributaries, the [Ohio River](/wiki/Ohio_River "Ohio
River") and the [Tennessee River](/wiki/Tennessee_River "Tennessee River").
The [Ohio](/wiki/Ohio_Valley "Ohio Valley") and
[Tennessee](/wiki/Tennessee_Valley "Tennessee Valley") Valleys and the
[Midwest](/wiki/Midwestern_U.S. "Midwestern U.S.") consist largely of rolling
hills, interior highlands and small mountains, jungly marsh and swampland near
the Ohio River, and productive [farmland](/wiki/Farmland "Farmland"),
stretching south to the [Gulf Coast](/wiki/U.S._Gulf_Coast "U.S. Gulf Coast").
The Midwest also has a vast amount of cave systems.

The [Great Plains](/wiki/Great_Plains "Great Plains") lie west of the
Mississippi River and east of the Rocky Mountains. A large portion of the
country's agricultural products are grown in the Great Plains. Before their
general conversion to farmland, the Great Plains were noted for their
extensive grasslands, from [tallgrass prairie](/wiki/Tallgrass_prairie
"Tallgrass prairie") in the eastern plains to [shortgrass
steppe](/wiki/Shortgrass_prairie "Shortgrass prairie") in the western [High
Plains](/wiki/High_Plains_\(United_States\) "High Plains \(United States\)").
Elevation rises gradually from less than a few hundred feet near the
Mississippi River to more than a mile high in the High Plains. The generally
low relief of the plains is broken in several places, most notably in the
[Ozark](/wiki/The_Ozarks "The Ozarks") and [Ouachita
Mountains](/wiki/Ouachita_Mountains "Ouachita Mountains"), which form the
[U.S. Interior Highlands](/wiki/U.S._Interior_Highlands "U.S. Interior
Highlands"), the only major mountainous region between the [Rocky
Mountains](/wiki/Rocky_Mountains "Rocky Mountains") and the [Appalachian
Mountains](/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains "Appalachian Mountains").[6][7]

The Great Plains come to an abrupt end at the [Rocky
Mountains](/wiki/Rocky_Mountains "Rocky Mountains"). The Rocky Mountains form
a large portion of the [Western U.S.](/wiki/Western_U.S. "Western U.S."),
entering from [Canada](/wiki/Canada "Canada") and stretching nearly to
[Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico"). The Rocky Mountain region is the highest
region of the United States by average elevation. The Rocky Mountains
generally contain fairly mild slopes and wider peaks compared to some of the
other great mountain ranges, with a few exceptions (such as the [Teton
Mountains](/wiki/Teton_Mountains "Teton Mountains") in [Wyoming](/wiki/Wyoming
"Wyoming") and the [Sawatch Range](/wiki/Sawatch_Range "Sawatch Range") in
[Colorado](/wiki/Colorado "Colorado")). The highest peaks of the Rockies are
found in Colorado, the tallest peak being [Mount Elbert](/wiki/Mount_Elbert
"Mount Elbert") at 14,440 ft (4,400 m). The Rocky Mountains contain some of
the most spectacular, and well known scenery in the world. In addition,
instead of being one generally continuous and solid mountain range, it is
broken up into a number of smaller, intermittent mountain ranges, forming a
large series of basins and valleys.

West of the Rocky Mountains lies the [Intermontane
Plateaus](/wiki/Intermontane_Plateaus "Intermontane Plateaus") (also known as
the [Intermountain West](/wiki/Intermountain_West "Intermountain West")), a
large, arid desert lying between the Rockies and the
[Cascades](/wiki/Cascade_Range "Cascade Range") and [Sierra
Nevada](/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_\(U.S.\) "Sierra Nevada \(U.S.\)") ranges. The
large southern portion, known as the [Great Basin](/wiki/Great_Basin "Great
Basin"), consists of salt flats, drainage basins, and many small north-south
mountain ranges. The [Southwest](/wiki/Southwestern_United_States
"Southwestern United States") is predominantly a low-lying desert region. A
portion known as the [Colorado Plateau](/wiki/Colorado_Plateau "Colorado
Plateau"), centered around the [Four Corners](/wiki/Four_Corners "Four
Corners") region, is considered to have some of the most spectacular scenery
in the world. It is accentuated in such national parks as [Grand
Canyon](/wiki/Grand_Canyon_National_Park "Grand Canyon National Park"),
[Arches](/wiki/Arches_National_Park "Arches National Park"), [Mesa Verde
National Park](/wiki/Mesa_Verde_National_Park "Mesa Verde National Park") and
[Bryce Canyon](/wiki/Bryce_Canyon_National_Park "Bryce Canyon National Park"),
among others. Other smaller Intermontane areas include the Columbia Plateau
covering eastern Washington, western Idaho and northeast Oregon and the Snake
River Plain in Southern Idaho.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Grand_Canyon_from_Moran_Point.jpeg/300px-
Grand_Canyon_from_Moran_Point.jpeg)](/wiki/File:Grand_Canyon_from_Moran_Point.jpeg)

[](/wiki/File:Grand_Canyon_from_Moran_Point.jpeg "Enlarge")

[The Grand Canyon](/wiki/The_Grand_Canyon "The Grand Canyon") from Moran
Point. The Grand Canyon is among the most famous locations in the country.

The Intermontane Plateaus come to an end at the [Cascade
Range](/wiki/Cascade_Range "Cascade Range") and the [Sierra
Nevada](/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_\(U.S.\) "Sierra Nevada \(U.S.\)"). The Cascades
consist of largely intermittent, volcanic mountains, many rising prominently
from the surrounding landscape. The Sierra Nevada, further south, is a high,
rugged, and dense mountain range. It contains the highest point in the
contiguous 48 states, [Mount Whitney](/wiki/Mount_Whitney "Mount Whitney")
(14,505 ft or 4,421 m). It is located at the boundary between California's
Inyo and Tulare counties, just 84.6 mi or 136.2 km west-northwest of the
lowest point in North America at the [Badwater Basin](/wiki/Badwater_Basin
"Badwater Basin") in [Death Valley National
Park](/wiki/Death_Valley_National_Park "Death Valley National Park") at 279 ft
or 85 m below sea level.[8]

These areas contain some spectacular scenery as well, as evidenced by such
national parks as [Yosemite](/wiki/Yosemite_National_Park "Yosemite National
Park") and [Mount Rainier](/wiki/Mount_Rainier_National_Park "Mount Rainier
National Park"). West of the Cascades and Sierra Nevada is a series of
valleys, such as the [Central Valley](/wiki/Central_Valley_\(California\)
"Central Valley \(California\)") in [California](/wiki/California
"California") and the [Willamette Valley](/wiki/Willamette_Valley "Willamette
Valley") in [Oregon](/wiki/Oregon "Oregon"). Along the coast is a series of
low mountain ranges known as the [Pacific Coast
Ranges](/wiki/Pacific_Coast_Ranges "Pacific Coast Ranges"). Much of the
[Pacific Northwest](/wiki/Pacific_Northwest "Pacific Northwest") coast is
inhabited by some of the densest vegetation outside of the
[Tropics](/wiki/Tropics "Tropics"), and also the tallest trees in the world
(the [Redwoods](/wiki/Coast_Redwood "Coast Redwood")).

Alaska contains some of the most dramatic and untapped scenery in the country.
Tall, prominent mountain ranges rise up sharply from broad, flat tundra
plains. On the islands off the south and southwest coast are many
[volcanoes](/wiki/Volcanoes "Volcanoes"). Hawaii, far to the south of Alaska
in the Pacific Ocean, is a chain of tropical, volcanic islands, popular as a
tourist destination for many from [East Asia](/wiki/East_Asia "East Asia") and
the mainland United States.

The territories of Puerto Rico and the U.S. Virgin Islands encompass a number
of tropical isles in the northeastern [Caribbean Sea](/wiki/Caribbean_Sea
"Caribbean Sea"). In the Pacific Ocean the territories of Guam and the
Northern Mariana Islands occupy the limestone and volcanic isles of the
[Mariana archipelago](/wiki/Mariana_Islands "Mariana Islands"), and American
Samoa (the only populated US territory in the southern hemisphere) encompasses
volcanic peaks and coral atolls in the eastern part of the [Samoan
Islands](/wiki/Samoan_Islands "Samoan Islands") chain.

### Physiographic
regions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Physiographic regions")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4c/US_physiographic_map.jpg/450px-
US_physiographic_map.jpg)](/wiki/File:US_physiographic_map.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:US_physiographic_map.jpg "Enlarge")

A [physiographical](/wiki/Physiography "Physiography") map of the contiguous
48 states of the U.S. The map indicates the age of the exposed surface as well
as the type of terrain.

The geography of the United States varies across their immense area. Within
the continental U.S., [eight distinct physiographic
divisions](/wiki/Physiographic_Regions_of_the_United_States "Physiographic
Regions of the United States") exist, though each is composed of several
smaller physiographic subdivisions.[9] These major divisions are:

  * [Laurentian Upland](/wiki/Laurentian_Upland "Laurentian Upland") \- part of the [Canadian Shield](/wiki/Canadian_Shield "Canadian Shield") that extends into the northern United States [Great Lakes](/wiki/Great_Lakes_\(North_America\) "Great Lakes \(North America\)") area.
  * [Atlantic Plain](/wiki/Atlantic_Plain "Atlantic Plain") \- the coastal regions of the eastern and southern parts includes the continental shelf, the [Atlantic Coast](/wiki/East_Coast_of_the_United_States "East Coast of the United States") and the [Gulf Coast](/wiki/U.S._Gulf_Coast "U.S. Gulf Coast").
  * [Appalachian Highlands](/wiki/Appalachian_Highlands "Appalachian Highlands") \- lying on the eastern side of the United States, it includes the [Appalachian Mountains](/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains "Appalachian Mountains"), the [Watchung Mountains](/wiki/Watchung_Mountains "Watchung Mountains"), the [Adirondacks](/wiki/Adirondacks "Adirondacks") and [New England](/wiki/New_England "New England") province originally containing the Great Eastern Forest, a stretch of mixed temperature and subtropical montane forests, some of which are rainforests.
  * [Interior Plains](/wiki/Interior_Plains "Interior Plains") \- part of the interior continental United States, it includes the [Great Plains](/wiki/Great_Plains "Great Plains"), as well as a number of highland and mountainous regions, like the [Black Hills](/wiki/Black_Hills "Black Hills"), dense cave systems, painted hills and badland features.
  * [Interior Highlands](/wiki/Interior_Highlands "Interior Highlands") \- also part of the interior continental United States, this division includes the [Ozark](/wiki/Ozark "Ozark") Plateau, the [Ouachita Mountains](/wiki/Ouachita_Mountains "Ouachita Mountains"), and other smaller mountain systems. This region is located largely in the warm temperate/subtropical moist and dry forest biomes.
  * [Rocky Mountain System](/wiki/Rocky_Mountains "Rocky Mountains") \- one branch of the [Cordilleran](/wiki/American_cordillera "American cordillera") system lying far inland in the western states.
  * [Intermontane Plateaus](/wiki/Geography_of_the_United_States_Intermontane_Plateaus "Geography of the United States Intermontane Plateaus") \- also divided into the [Columbia Plateau](/wiki/Columbia_Plateau "Columbia Plateau"), the [Colorado Plateau](/wiki/Colorado_Plateau "Colorado Plateau") and the [Basin and Range Province](/wiki/Basin_and_Range_Province "Basin and Range Province"), it is a system of plateaus, basins, ranges and gorges between the Rocky and Pacific Mountain Systems. It is the setting for the [Grand Canyon](/wiki/Grand_Canyon "Grand Canyon"), the [Great Basin](/wiki/Great_Basin "Great Basin") and [Death Valley](/wiki/Death_Valley "Death Valley").
  * [Pacific Mountain System](/wiki/Pacific_Coast_Ranges "Pacific Coast Ranges") \- the coastal mountain ranges and features in the [west coast of the United States](/wiki/West_Coast_of_the_United_States "West Coast of the United States").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Scipio_Township_near_Republic.jpg/300px-
Scipio_Township_near_Republic.jpg)](/wiki/File:Scipio_Township_near_Republic.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Scipio_Township_near_Republic.jpg "Enlarge")

Much of the central United States is covered by relatively flat, arable land.
This aerial photo was taken over northern [Ohio](/wiki/Ohio "Ohio").

The Atlantic coast of the United States is low, with minor exceptions. The
Appalachian Highland owes its oblique northeast-southwest trend to crustal
deformations which in very early geological time gave a beginning to what
later came to be the Appalachian mountain system. This system had its climax
of deformation so long ago (probably in [Permian](/wiki/Permian "Permian")
time) that it has since then been very generally reduced to moderate or low
relief. It owes its present-day altitude either to renewed elevations along
the earlier lines or to the survival of the most resistant rocks as residual
mountains. The oblique trend of this coast would be even more pronounced but
for a comparatively modern crustal movement, causing a depression in the
northeast resulting in an encroachment of the sea upon the land. Additionally,
the southeastern section has undergone an elevation resulting in the advance
of the land upon the sea.

While the Atlantic coast is relatively low, the Pacific coast is, with few
exceptions, hilly or mountainous. This coast has been defined chiefly by
geologically recent crustal deformations, and hence still preserves a greater
relief than that of the Atlantic. The low Atlantic coast and the hilly or
mountainous Pacific coast foreshadow the leading features in the distribution
of mountains within the United States.

The east coast Appalachian system, originally forest covered, is relatively
low and narrow and is bordered on the southeast and south by an important
coastal plain. The [Cordilleran system](/wiki/American_cordillera "American
cordillera") on the western side of the continent is lofty, broad and
complicated having two branches, the Rocky Mountain System and the Pacific
Mountain System. In between these mountain systems lie the Intermontaine
Plateaus. Both the [Columbia River](/wiki/Columbia_River "Columbia River") and
[Colorado River](/wiki/Colorado_River "Colorado River") rise far inland near
the easternmost members of the Cordilleran system, and flow through plateaus
and intermontaine basins to the ocean. Heavy forests cover the northwest
coast, but elsewhere trees are found only on the higher ranges below the
Alpine region. The [intermontane](/wiki/Intermontane "Intermontane") valleys,
plateaus and basins range from treeless to desert with the most arid region
being in the southwest.

The Laurentian Highlands, the Interior Plains and the Interior Highlands lie
between the two coasts, stretching from the [Gulf of
Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of Mexico") northward, far beyond the
national boundary, to the [Arctic Ocean](/wiki/Arctic_Ocean "Arctic Ocean").
The central plains are divided by a hardly perceptible height of land into a
[Canadian](/wiki/Canada "Canada") and a United States portion. It is from the
United States side, that the great [Mississippi](/wiki/Mississippi_River
"Mississippi River") system discharges southward to the Gulf of Mexico. The
upper Mississippi and some of the [Ohio](/wiki/Ohio_River "Ohio River") basin
is the semi-arid prairie region, with trees originally only along the
watercourses. The uplands towards the Appalachians were included in the great
eastern forested area, while the western part of the plains has so dry a
climate that its native plant life is scanty, and in the south it is
practically barren.

Elevation extremes:

  * Lowest point: [Death Valley](/wiki/Death_Valley "Death Valley"), [Inyo County, California](/wiki/Inyo_County,_California "Inyo County, California") −280 ft (−85.3 m)
  * Highest point: [Denali](/wiki/Denali "Denali"), [Denali Borough, Alaska](/wiki/Denali_Borough,_Alaska "Denali Borough, Alaska") 20,310 ft (6,190.5 m)

##
Climate[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Climate")]

Main article: [Climate of the United
States](/wiki/Climate_of_the_United_States "Climate of the United States")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/US_50_states_K%C3%B6ppen.svg/350px-
US_50_states_K%C3%B6ppen.svg.png)](/wiki/File:US_50_states_K%C3%B6ppen.svg)

[](/wiki/File:US_50_states_K%C3%B6ppen.svg "Enlarge")

[Köppen climate types](/wiki/K%C3%B6ppen_climate_classification "Köppen
climate classification") of the US

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d3/Average_precipitation_in_the_lower_48_states_of_the_USA.png/350px-
Average_precipitation_in_the_lower_48_states_of_the_USA.png)](/wiki/File:Average_precipitation_in_the_lower_48_states_of_the_USA.png)

[](/wiki/File:Average_precipitation_in_the_lower_48_states_of_the_USA.png
"Enlarge")

A map of average precipitation across the contiguous US.

Due to its large size and wide range of geographic features, the United States
contains examples of nearly every global climate. The climate is subtropical
in the [Southern United States](/wiki/Southern_United_States "Southern United
States"), tropical in [Hawaii](/wiki/Hawaii "Hawaii") and southern
[Florida](/wiki/Florida "Florida"), polar in Alaska, semiarid in the Great
Plains west of the [100th meridian](/wiki/100th_meridian_west "100th meridian
west"), Mediterranean in coastal [California](/wiki/California "California")
and arid in the [Great Basin](/wiki/Great_Basin "Great Basin") and the
[Southwest](/wiki/Southwest "Southwest"). Its comparatively favorable
agricultural climate contributed (in part) to the country's rise as a world
power, with infrequent severe drought in the major agricultural regions, a
general lack of widespread flooding, and a mainly temperate climate that
receives adequate precipitation.

The main influence on U.S. weather is the [polar jet stream](/wiki/Jet_stream
"Jet stream") which migrates northward into Canada in the summer months, and
then southward into the USA in the winter months. The jet stream brings in
large low pressure systems from the northern [Pacific
Ocean](/wiki/Pacific_Ocean "Pacific Ocean") that enter the US mainland over
the Pacific Northwest. The [Cascade Range](/wiki/Cascade_Range "Cascade
Range"), [Sierra Nevada](/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_\(U.S.\) "Sierra Nevada
\(U.S.\)"), and [Rocky Mountains](/wiki/Rocky_Mountains "Rocky Mountains")
pick up most of the moisture from these systems as they move eastward. Greatly
diminished by the time they reach the High Plains, much of the moisture has
been sapped by the [orographic
effect](/wiki/Precipitation_\(meteorology\)#Orographic_precipitation
"Precipitation \(meteorology\)") as it is forced over several mountain ranges.

Once it moves over the Great Plains, uninterrupted flat land allows it to
reorganize and can lead to major clashes of air masses. In addition, moisture
from the [Gulf of Mexico](/wiki/Gulf_of_Mexico "Gulf of Mexico") is often
drawn northward. When combined with a powerful jet stream, this can lead to
violent thunderstorms, especially during spring and summer. Sometimes during
winter these storms can combine with another low pressure system as they move
up the East Coast and into the [Atlantic Ocean](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic
Ocean"), where they intensify rapidly. These storms are known as
[Nor'easters](/wiki/Nor%27easter "Nor'easter") and often bring widespread,
heavy rain, wind, and snowfall to [New England](/wiki/New_England "New
England"). The uninterrupted grasslands of the Great Plains also lead to some
of the most extreme climate swings in the world. Temperatures can rise or drop
rapidly and winds can be extreme, and the flow of heat waves or Arctic air
masses often advance uninterrupted through the plains.

The [Great Basin](/wiki/Great_Basin "Great Basin") and [Columbia
Plateau](/wiki/Columbia_Plateau "Columbia Plateau") (the [Intermontane
Plateaus](/wiki/Intermontane_Plateaus "Intermontane Plateaus")) are arid or
semiarid regions that lie in the rain shadow of the
[Cascades](/wiki/Cascade_Mountains "Cascade Mountains") and [Sierra
Nevada](/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_\(U.S.\) "Sierra Nevada \(U.S.\)"). Precipitation
averages less than 15 inches (38 cm). The [Southwest](/wiki/Southwestern_U.S.
"Southwestern U.S.") is a hot desert, with temperatures exceeding 100 °F (37.8
°C) for several weeks at a time in summer. The Southwest and the Great Basin
are also affected by the [monsoon](/wiki/Monsoon "Monsoon") from the [Gulf of
California](/wiki/Gulf_of_California "Gulf of California") from July to
September, which brings localized but often severe thunderstorms to the
region.

Much of California consists of a [Mediterranean
climate](/wiki/Mediterranean_climate "Mediterranean climate"), with sometimes
excessive rainfall from October–April and nearly no rain the rest of the year.
In the [Pacific Northwest](/wiki/Pacific_Northwest "Pacific Northwest") rain
falls year-round, but is much heavier during winter and spring. The mountains
of the west receive abundant precipitation and very heavy snowfall. The
Cascades are one of the snowiest places in the world, with some places
averaging over 600 inches (1,524 cm) of snow annually, but the lower
elevations closer to the coast receive very little snow.

Florida has a [subtropical climate](/wiki/Subtropical_climate "Subtropical
climate") in the northern part of the state and a [tropical
climate](/wiki/Tropical_climate "Tropical climate") in the southern part of
the state. Summers are wet and winters are dry in Florida. Annually much of
Florida, as well as the deep southern states, are frost-free. The mild winters
of Florida allow a massive tropical fruit industry to thrive in the central
part of the state, making the US second to only Brazil in [citrus
production](/wiki/Citrus_production "Citrus production") in the world.

Another significant (but localized) weather effect is [lake-effect
snow](/wiki/Lake-effect_snow "Lake-effect snow") that falls south and east of
the [Great Lakes](/wiki/Great_Lakes "Great Lakes"), especially in the hilly
portions of the [Upper Peninsula](/wiki/Upper_Peninsula "Upper Peninsula") of
[Michigan](/wiki/Michigan "Michigan") and on the [Tug Hill
Plateau](/wiki/Tug_Hill_Plateau "Tug Hill Plateau") in [New
York](/wiki/New_York_\(state\) "New York \(state\)"). The lake effect dumped
well over 5 feet (1.52 m) of snow in the area of Buffalo, New York throughout
the 2006-2007 winter. The [Wasatch Front](/wiki/Wasatch_Front "Wasatch Front")
and [Wasatch Range](/wiki/Wasatch_Range "Wasatch Range") in [Utah](/wiki/Utah
"Utah") can also receive significant lake effect accumulations from the [Great
Salt Lake](/wiki/Great_Salt_Lake "Great Salt Lake").

###
Extremes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Extremes")]

See also: [U.S. state temperature
extremes](/wiki/U.S._state_temperature_extremes "U.S. state temperature
extremes")

In northern Alaska, [tundra](/wiki/Tundra "Tundra") and [arctic](/wiki/Arctic
"Arctic") conditions predominate, where the temperature has fallen as low as
−80 °F (−62.2 °C).[10] On the other end of the spectrum, [Death Valley,
California](/wiki/Death_Valley_National_Park "Death Valley National Park")
once reached 134 °F (56.7 °C), the highest temperature ever recorded on
Earth.[11][12]

On average, the mountains of the western states receive the highest levels of
snowfall on Earth. The greatest annual snowfall level is at [Mount
Rainier](/wiki/Mount_Rainier "Mount Rainier") in
[Washington](/wiki/Washington_\(state\) "Washington \(state\)"), at 692 inches
(1,758 cm); the record there was 1,122 inches (2,850 cm) in the winter of
1971–72. This record was broken by the Mt. Baker Ski Area in northwestern
Washington which reported 1,140 inches (2,896 cm) of snowfall for the 1998-99
snowfall season. Other places with significant snowfall outside the Cascade
Range are the [Wasatch Mountains](/wiki/Wasatch_Mountains "Wasatch
Mountains"), near the [Great Salt Lake](/wiki/Great_Salt_Lake "Great Salt
Lake"), the [San Juan Mountains](/wiki/San_Juan_Mountains "San Juan
Mountains") in [Colorado](/wiki/Colorado "Colorado"), and the [Sierra
Nevada](/wiki/Sierra_Nevada_\(U.S.\) "Sierra Nevada \(U.S.\)"), near [Lake
Tahoe](/wiki/Lake_Tahoe "Lake Tahoe").

In the east, the region near the Great Lakes and the mountains of the
Northeast receive the most snowfall, although such snowfall levels do not near
snowfall levels in the western United States. Along the northwestern Pacific
coast, rainfall is greater than anywhere else in the continental U.S., with
[Quinault Rainforest](/wiki/Quinault_Rainforest "Quinault Rainforest") in
Washington having an average of 137 inches (348 cm).[13] Hawaii receives even
more, with 460 inches (1,168 cm) measured annually on [Mount
Waialeale](/wiki/Mount_Waialeale "Mount Waialeale"), in [Kauai](/wiki/Kauai
"Kauai"). The [Mojave Desert](/wiki/Mojave_Desert "Mojave Desert"), in the
southwest, is home to the driest locale in the U.S. [Yuma,
Arizona](/wiki/Yuma,_Arizona "Yuma, Arizona"), has an average of 2.63 inches
(6.7 cm) of [precipitation](/wiki/Precipitation_\(meteorology\) "Precipitation
\(meteorology\)") each year.[14]

In central portions of the U.S., [tornadoes](/wiki/Tornado "Tornado") are more
common than anywhere else on Earth[15] and touch down most commonly in the
spring and summer. Deadly and destructive [hurricanes](/wiki/Hurricane
"Hurricane") occur almost every year along the Atlantic seaboard and the Gulf
of Mexico. The Appalachian region and the Midwest experience the worst floods,
though virtually no area in the U.S. is immune to flooding. The Southwest has
the worst droughts; one is thought to have lasted over 500 years and to have
hurt [Ancestral Pueblo peoples](/wiki/Ancestral_Pueblo_peoples "Ancestral
Pueblo peoples").[16] The West is affected by large wildfires each year.

## Natural
disasters[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Natural disasters")]

The United States is affected by a variety of [natural
disasters](/wiki/Natural_disaster "Natural disaster") yearly. Although drought
is rare, it has occasionally caused major disruption, such as during the [Dust
Bowl](/wiki/Dust_Bowl "Dust Bowl") (1931–1942). Farmland failed throughout the
Plains, entire regions were virtually depopulated, and dust storms ravaged the
land.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d0/Dimmitt_Tornado1_-_NOAA.jpg/300px-
Dimmitt_Tornado1_-_NOAA.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dimmitt_Tornado1_-_NOAA.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Dimmitt_Tornado1_-_NOAA.jpg "Enlarge")

A powerful tornado near [Dimmitt, Texas](/wiki/Dimmitt,_Texas "Dimmitt,
Texas") on June 2, 1995.

### Tornadoes and
hurricanes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Tornadoes and hurricanes")]

The Great Plains and Midwest, due to the contrasting air masses, see frequent
severe thunderstorms and tornado outbreaks during spring and summer with
around 1,000 tornadoes occurring each year.[17] The strip of land from north
[Texas](/wiki/Texas "Texas") north to [Kansas](/wiki/Kansas "Kansas") and
[Nebraska](/wiki/Nebraska "Nebraska") and east into
[Tennessee](/wiki/Tennessee "Tennessee") is known as [Tornado
Alley](/wiki/Tornado_Alley "Tornado Alley"), where many houses have tornado
shelters and many towns have tornado sirens due to the very frequent tornado
formations in the region.

Hurricanes are another natural disaster found in the US, which can hit
anywhere along the [Gulf Coast](/wiki/U.S._Gulf_Coast "U.S. Gulf Coast") or
the [Atlantic Coast](/wiki/East_Coast_of_the_United_States "East Coast of the
United States") as well as Hawaii in the Pacific Ocean. Particularly at risk
are the central and southern [Texas](/wiki/Texas "Texas") coasts, the area
from southeastern [Louisiana](/wiki/Louisiana "Louisiana") east to the
[Florida Panhandle](/wiki/Florida_Panhandle "Florida Panhandle"), peninsular
[Florida](/wiki/Florida "Florida"), and the [Outer Banks](/wiki/Outer_Banks
"Outer Banks") of [North Carolina](/wiki/North_Carolina "North Carolina"),
although any portion of the coast could be struck.

Hurricane season runs from June 1 to November 30, with a peak from mid-August
through early October. Some of the more devastating hurricanes have included
the [Galveston Hurricane of 1900](/wiki/Galveston_Hurricane_of_1900 "Galveston
Hurricane of 1900"), [Hurricane Andrew](/wiki/Hurricane_Andrew "Hurricane
Andrew") in 1992, and [Hurricane Katrina](/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina "Hurricane
Katrina") in 2005.

Hurricanes (known as cyclones in the Pacific Ocean) fail to landfall on the
Pacific Coast of the United States due to water temperatures being too cool to
sustain them. However, the remnants of tropical cyclones from the Eastern
Pacific occasionally impact the western United States, bringing moderate to
heavy rainfall.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/42/Hurricane_katrina_damage_gulfport_mississippi.jpg/300px-
Hurricane_katrina_damage_gulfport_mississippi.jpg)](/wiki/File:Hurricane_katrina_damage_gulfport_mississippi.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Hurricane_katrina_damage_gulfport_mississippi.jpg "Enlarge")

Total devastation in [Gulfport, Mississippi](/wiki/Gulfport,_Mississippi
"Gulfport, Mississippi") caused by storm surge from [Hurricane
Katrina](/wiki/Hurricane_Katrina "Hurricane Katrina") in 2005.

###
Flooding[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Flooding")]

Occasional severe flooding is experienced. There was the [Great Mississippi
Flood of 1927](/wiki/Great_Mississippi_Flood_of_1927 "Great Mississippi Flood
of 1927"), the [Great Flood of 1993](/wiki/Great_Flood_of_1993 "Great Flood of
1993"), and widespread flooding and mudslides caused by the 1982–83 [El
Niño](/wiki/El_Ni%C3%B1o "El Niño") event in the western United States.
Localized flooding can, however, occur anywhere, and mudslides from heavy rain
can cause problems in any mountainous area, particularly the Southwest. Large
stretches of desert shrub in the west can fuel the spread of
[wildfires](/wiki/Wildfire "Wildfire"). The narrow canyons of many mountain
areas in the west and severe thunderstorm activity during the summer lead to
sometimes devastating [flash floods](/wiki/Flash_flood "Flash flood") as well,
while [nor'easter](/wiki/Nor%27easter "Nor'easter") snowstorms can bring
activity to a halt throughout the Northeast (although heavy snowstorms can
occur almost anywhere).

###
Geologic[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Geologic")]

The West Coast of the continental United States and areas of Alaska (including
the [Aleutian Islands](/wiki/Aleutian_Islands "Aleutian Islands"), the
[Alaskan Peninsula](/wiki/Alaskan_Peninsula "Alaskan Peninsula") and southern
Alaskan coast) make up part of the [Pacific Ring of
Fire](/wiki/Pacific_Ring_of_Fire "Pacific Ring of Fire"), an area of heavy
tectonic and volcanic activity that is the source of 90% of the world's
earthquakes.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_] The American Northwest sees the highest
concentration of active volcanoes in the United States, in
[Washington](/wiki/Washington_\(state\) "Washington \(state\)"),
[Oregon](/wiki/Oregon "Oregon") and [northern
California](/wiki/Northern_California "Northern California") along the
[Cascade Mountains](/wiki/Cascade_Mountains "Cascade Mountains"). There are
several active volcanoes located in the islands of Hawaii, including Kilauea
in ongoing eruption since 1983, but they do not typically adversely affect the
inhabitants of the islands. There has not been a major life-threatening
eruption on the Hawaiian islands since the 17th century. Volcanic eruptions
can occasionally be devastating, such as in the [1980 eruption of Mount St.
Helens](/wiki/1980_eruption_of_Mount_St._Helens "1980 eruption of Mount St.
Helens") in Washington.

The Ring of Fire makes [California](/wiki/California "California") and
southern [Alaska](/wiki/Alaska "Alaska") particularly vulnerable to
[earthquakes](/wiki/Earthquake "Earthquake"). Earthquakes can cause extensive
damage, such as the [1906 San Francisco
earthquake](/wiki/1906_San_Francisco_earthquake "1906 San Francisco
earthquake") or the 1964 [Good Friday earthquake](/wiki/Good_Friday_earthquake
"Good Friday earthquake") near [Anchorage, Alaska](/wiki/Anchorage,_Alaska
"Anchorage, Alaska"). California is well known for seismic activity, and
requires large structures to be [earthquake
resistant](/wiki/Earthquake_resistant_structures "Earthquake resistant
structures") to minimize loss of life and property.[18] Outside of devastating
earthquakes, California experiences minor earthquakes on a regular basis.

There have been about 100 significant earthquakes annually from 2010 to 2012.
Past averages were 21 a year. This is believed to be due to the deep disposal
of wastewater from [fracking](/wiki/Fracking "Fracking"). None has exceeded a
magnitude of 5.6, and no one has been killed.[19]

### Other natural
disasters[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Other natural disasters")]

Other natural disasters include: [tsunamis](/wiki/Tsunami "Tsunami") around
Pacific Basin, mud slides in California, and forest fires in the western half
of the contiguous U.S. Although drought is relatively rare, it has
occasionally caused major economic and social disruption, such as during the
[Dust Bowl](/wiki/Dust_Bowl "Dust Bowl") (1931–1942), which resulted in
widespread crop failures and duststorms, beginning in the southern Great
Plains and reaching to the Atlantic Ocean.

lands[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Geography_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: Public lands")]

Exclusive economic zones of the United States, including [insular

The United States holds many areas for the use and enjoyment of the public.
These include [National Parks](/wiki/National_park "National park"), [National
Monuments](/wiki/National_Monument_\(United_States\) "National Monument
\(United States\)"), [National Forests](/wiki/United_States_National_Forest
"United States National Forest"), [Wilderness
areas](/wiki/Strict_Nature_Reserve/Wilderness_Area "Strict Nature
Reserve/Wilderness Area"), and other areas. For lists of areas, see the
following articles:
